article.title: Alternatives to the stochastic "noise vector" approach

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the two-bump distribution in the bottom figure of Figure 1 indicate?
choices: The presence of a phase transition in the vicinity of the simulated temperature.
A large discrepancy between the stochastic estimator and the exact value of  ⟨ψψ⟩.
The failure of the Chebyshev approximation in this temperature regime.
An insufficient number of noise vectors used in the stochastic estimation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the left panel of Figure 2 depict?
choices: The distribution of eigenvalues of the Dirac operator.
A Chebyshev polynomial approximation of a bandpass filter.
The eigenvalue count as a function of the eigenvalue.
The spectral density of the staggered Dirac operator.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 illustrate about the spectrum of the matrix A = (i∂/∂μ)(D(μ))⁻¹?
choices: The eigenvalues are all real and positive.
The eigenvalues are clustered around the origin.
The eigenvalues are complex and their distribution changes with lattice size.
The eigenvalues are independent of the temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Table 1 demonstrate about the Chebyshev approximation method?
choices: It fails to accurately estimate higher moments of the Dirac operator.
It requires a large number of noise vectors to achieve reasonable accuracy.
It provides a computationally efficient way to estimate traces of powers of the inverse Dirac operator.
It is only applicable for small lattice sizes.
